description.narrative: Global Opportunities for Long-term Development: Integrated Sound Management of Mercury in Indonesias ASGM Sector (GOLD: ISMIA)

activity-description.narrative: Jakarta for PMU office and there are 6 project locations: Kuantan Singingi district (Riau Province), Kulonprogo district (D.I Yogyakarta Province), West Lombok District (West Nusa Tenggara Province); North Gorontalo district (Gorontalo Province); North Minahasa District (North Sulawesi Province), an
West Lombok District (West Nusa Tenggara Province)

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).

description.narrative:
5 new partnership mechanisms with funding for gender friendly and sustainable management solutions of natural resources, ecosystem services, chemicals and waste at national level.
200,970 direct project beneficiaries (80,390 females and 120,580 males) for which the risk of mercury exposure has been reduced.
National systems have the capacity to assess, plan, and implement sustainable and mercury-free interventions in the ASGM sector.
Enabling environment created through improved national policies and regulatory frameworks for ASGM and mercury phase-out in the ASGM sector.
Loans for the purchase of mercury-free processing equipment/investments are accessible to legalized ASGM miners and cooperatives.
10 ASGM groups (of which 20% of the miners are women) are capacitated to apply for loans for mercury-free processing equipment/investments.
15 tonnes of mercury avoided through the introduction of BEP, BAT and socially and environmentally sound ASGM practices.
60 ASGM groups (of which 20% of the miners are women) supported in their formalization processes leading to more sustainable income opportunities and safer working conditions.
Route to market for mercury-free gold improved/established.
20,000 people (8,000 females and 12,000 males) of whom awareness has been raised on the dangers of mercury and ways to reduce its use in ASGM.
M&E and adaptive management applied in response to needs and Mid-Term Evaluation findings.
Project results, experiences, lessons-learned and best practices are captured, published, and taken up by the GEF GOLD Global Dissemination Platform for national and global dissemination, using report templates provided by the GEF GOLD global component where appropriate.

comment.narrative:
No partnership mechanisms exist that provide access to funding for gender friendly sustainable management solutions in the ASGM sector.
0 direct project beneficiaries.
The devolution of ASGM responsibilities and the administration of mining regulations from the national level to the provinces/districts without concomitant increases in funding, staffing, or capacity building in those regional offices is currently hampering formalization efforts.
Harmonization between Law 4/2009 (Mineral and Coal Mining Law), Law 23/2014 (Regional Governance), Law 11/2017 (Minamata ratification) and Law 6/2014 (Village Law) is needed to ensure that responsibilities of entities with respect to ASGM are clear and do not conflict or overlap. Districts and provinces currently lack regulations (and guidance documents on implementation) that are harmonized with the Mining Law and the new Regional Governance Law. This is hampering ASGM formalization efforts.
4 financial mechanisms available, which have not been tailored to be able to serve the ASGM sector. These include:
Village fund (BUMDes Dana Desa = 61,500 USD/year/village. However, 0 BUMDes mechanisms have been applied for ASGM to date. BLU = 1.5 million USD/year. However, 0 BLU mechanisms have been applied for ASGM to date. BRI KUR = 15,400 USD/year/project. However, 0 KUR from BRI mechanisms have been applied for ASGM to date. BNI 46 = 10.8 million USD/year. However, 0 BNI environmental grants and/or loans have been allocated to ASGM to date. For 6 villages baseline potential access to funding is: 12.7 million US$
In the 6 selected project areas, none of the ASGM miners have been trained on how to access financing.
0 ASGM loan applications developed. 0 ASGM loan applications approved.
Preliminary estimates from research and PPG field work suggest cumulative emissions among all 6 target communities could exceed 13 tonnes of mercury per year: 1. Bole Bolange District, Gorontalo Province – 1.15 tonnes Hg/yr 2. Sekotong-Wes

• 1 new partnership mechanisms with funding for gender friendly and sustainable management solutions of chemicals and waste established at national and/or subnational level.
• 70,000 direct project beneficiaries (12,000 female and 18,000 male) for which the risk of mercury exposure has been reduced.
• Capacity of 7 government entities increased to improve their capacity to assess, plan, and implement sustainable and mercury-free interventions in the ASGM sector.
• 6 policies, regulations and standards revised and/or developed to improve the enabling environment for ASGM and mercury phase-out in the ASGM sector.
• 1 new/improved financial products/mechanisms (including women friendly financial products) established for the ASGM sector.
• US$ 24 million (Total amount of funding) available to the ASGM sector through existing/new financial mechanisms.
• US$ 2.8 million (Total amount of funding) allocated to the ASGM sector through approved loans by Year 3.
• 3 miner groups (of which 20% of the miners are women) are trained in developing a loan/investment application (incl. undertaking technical and financial feasibility studies).
• 10 applications developed (with technical support of the project).
• 20% of loan applications (developed with technical support of the project) approved.
• Mercury use/releases from ASGM avoided by 2 tonnes/year.
• 100 kg of gold produced per year without mercury.
• At least 20 mining groups (of which 20% of the miners are women) supported in their formalization processes.
• 75 kg of mercury-free gold sold to the formal market.
• Awareness raised of 8,000 people (5,000 female and 7,000 male) on the dangers of mercury and ways to reduce its use in ASGM.
• 10 of GEF M&E requirements met and adaptive management applied in response to needs and Mid-term Evaluation (MTE) findings.
• 1 GEF GOLD country project webpage maintained.
• Country project participated in 1 Global ASGM Forum, 1 Annual Programme Conference, and 12 monthly programme/project calls on a yearly basis.
• Opportunities for communication of project activity results at a global level are identified on a quarterly basis in collaboration with the GEF GOLD global component.
• On a quarterly basis, information on project progress (using agreed metrics and templates provided by the GEF GOLD global component where appropriate) is submitted to the GEF GOLD global component.

In 2020, UNDP project to support ASGM sector for mercury phase out has indicated its progress towards outcome targets. The results in 2020 have been indicated through the completion of the availability of initial partnership mechanisms with banks to provide funding to support ASGM sector to implement best practices for mercury phase-out. Project was documenting there were 38,000 direct project beneficiaries (12,000 female and 18,000 male) has improved gold mining techniques which reduce the mercury exposure risks. The capacities of 16 government entities also increased in assessing and planning the sustainable and mercury-free interventions in the ASGM.
Importance support held by UNDP to assist government and stakeholders in developing guideline for RAD (regional action plan) PPM, to ensure the creation of enabling and supportive environment for ASGM and regional actions for mercury phase-out. It is notable to acknowledge the project has succeed in establishing 1 new/improved financial products/mechanisms (including women friendly financial products) for the ASGM sector in 2020. The No one Left Behind, has been incorporated in project strategy by recognizing and adopting the most vulnerable groups interest and needs, especially women. Although, no specific funds for ASGM are ready by financial entities, but the UNDP with govt counterpart has set a fundamental initiative to continue the the process.
The project also has strengthened capacity of gold miners, the project has pilot to 8 miner groups (of which 20% of the miners are women), to develop a loan/investment application (incl. undertaking technical and financial feasibility studies). As the following result, loan applications development are now in progress, written by the miner and developed with reference to their background and context of experiences, and convey miners specific needs, including needs based on gender, if any.
Project has approached and engaged at least 10 mining groups (of which 20% of the miners are women) to support any works formalization processes conducted in 2020. To ensure none of mercury-free gold sold to the formal market, UNDP has initiated the cooperation with formal gold buyer i.e. PT. ANTAM . Massive awareness raising was conducted to 4,236 people (1,734 female (41%) and 2,502 male (59%)) on the dangers of mercury and ways to reduce its use in ASGM and has increased awareness of these people. 10 GEF M&E requirements met and adaptive management applied in response to needs and Mid-term Evaluation (MTE) findings. The GEF GOLD country project webpage was maintained and go public as it can be accessed by wide audiences.
This year project has contributed to mercury use/releases from ASGM avoided by 5 tonnes/year and 0.87 tonnes of gold produced per year without mercury.
To enlarge the network and disseminated best practices, UNDP with Gov counterpart also participated in 1 Global ASGM Forum, 1 Annual Programme Conference, and 12 monthly programme/project calls on a yearly basis. Dissemination of the results from Indonesia also shared to GEF global component platform.

• US$ 13 million (Total amount of funding) available to the ASGM sector through existing/new financial mechanisms.
• US$ 2.8 million (Total amount of funding) allocated to the ASGM sector through approved loans by Year 3.
• 1 miner groups (of which 20% of the miners are women) are trained in developing a loan/investment application (incl. undertaking technical and financial feasibility studies).
• Preparation of applications developed (with technical support of the project).
• 10% of loan applications (developed with technical support of the project) approved.
• Mercury use/releases from ASGM avoided by 1 tonnes/year.
• 50 kg of gold produced per year without mercury.
• At least 10 mining groups (of which 20% of the miners are women) supported in their formalization processes.
• 25 kg of mercury-free gold sold to the formal market.
• Awareness raised of 4,000 people (5,000 female and 7,000 male) on the dangers of mercury and ways to reduce its use in ASGM.
• 5 of GEF M&E requirements met and adaptive management applied in response to needs and Mid-term Evaluation (MTE) findings.
• 1 GEF GOLD country project webpage maintained.
• Country project participated in 1 Global ASGM Forum, 1 Annual Programme Conference, and 12 monthly programme/project calls on a yearly basis.
• Opportunities for communication of project activity results at a global level are identified on a quarterly basis in collaboration with the GEF GOLD global component.
• On a quarterly basis, information on project progress (using agreed metrics and templates provided by the GEF GOLD global component where appropriate) is submitted to the GEF GOLD global component.

In the first-year of UNDP’s support to the National Action Plan (NAP) for mercury phase-out in 2023, MOEF conducted mapping on government capacity in managing ASGM and has assisted 15 provinces to enhance capacity to develop Regional Action Plan (RAP) for mercury reduction and elimination. Particular support given to artisanal and small-scale gold miners, by providing awareness raising module on mercury-free gold mining practices.

• Two (2) new partnership mechanisms with funding for gender friendly and sustainable management solutions of chemicals and waste established at national and/or subnational level.
• 120,585 direct project beneficiaries (48,234 female and 72,351 male) for which the risk of mercury exposure has been reduced.
• Capacity of 11 government entities increased to improve their capacity to assess, plan, and implement sustainable and mercury-free interventions in the ASGM sector.
• Eight (8) policies, regulations and standards revised and/or developed to improve the enabling environment for ASGM and mercury phase-out in the ASGM sector.
• Two (2) new/improved financial products/mechanisms (including women friendly financial products) established for the ASGM sector.
• US$ 35 million (Total amount of funding) available to the ASGM sector through existing/new financial mechanisms.
• US$ 2.8 million (Total amount of funding) allocated to the ASGM sector through approved loans.
• Five (5) miner groups (of which 20% of the miners are women) are trained in developing a loan/investment application (incl. undertaking technical and financial feasibility studies).
• Ten (10) loan applications developed (with technical support of the project).
• 50% of loan applications (developed with technical support of the project) approved.
• Mercury use/releases from ASGM avoided by 5 tonnes.
• 150 kg of gold produced per year without mercury.
• At least 30 mining groups (of which 20% of the miners are women) supported in their formalization processes.
• 100 kg of mercury-free gold sold to the formal market.
• Awareness raised of 12,000 people (5,000 female and 7,000 male) on the dangers of mercury and ways to reduce its use in ASGM.
• 15 of GEF M&E requirements met and adaptive management applied in response to needs and Mid-term Evaluation (MTE) findings.
• One (1) GEF GOLD country project webpage maintained.
• Country project participated in 1 Global ASGM Forum, 1 Annual Programme Conference, and 12 monthly programme/project calls on a yearly basis.
• Opportunities for communication of project activity results at a global level are identified on a quarterly basis in collaboration with the GEF GOLD global component.
• On a quarterly basis, information on project progress (using agreed metrics and templates provided by the GEF GOLD global component where appropriate) is submitted to the GEF GOLD global component.

• 39 government entities or 344 government staff (47% were women) were trained • 29 regulations developed for mercury phase-out in the ASGM sector (13 regulations for Gender), including Guideline on Good Mining Practices and Guideline on Responsible Village for ASGM were developed • 5 financial mechanisms established (LVGA and banks-BNI&BRI) and on going approach with CSR Angkasapura, Pegadaian and LPDB-Kemenkop • Circa USD 2 billion funds are available for SME business including ASGM • USD 108,947 in loans were approved (questionnaire, banks and cooperative) • 15 miner groups were trained in developing a loan/investment application • 35 loan applications developed • 100% loan applications that were submitted to the financial institutions were approved • 11.6 tonnes mercury avoided • 2.23 tons mercury-free gold produced • 18 mining cooperatives established • 35 miner groups supported for formalization (claimed from the number of IPRs stated on WPR document submitted to MoMER) • 754 gram mercury-free gold sold to formal market • Developed visibility study on formal market scheme and National Standard on mercury-free processing • 15,637 (47% were women) were informed about the dangers of mercury • 18 GEF M&E requirements were developed • 1 project website developed • Involved in Annual country project meeting, COP Minamata and PM calls • Participated in communication calls • Quarterly report submitted to planetGOLD • Project publications submitted to the project website • 100% of policies, regulations and standards assessed in terms of gender dimensions • Training module on financial access has been elaborated with gender aspect • At least 2 women mining groups, and mining groups containing women, will be trained in developing loan/investment applications • Existing financial products assessed in terms of accessibility and suitability for women and men mining groups • Involving women miners in formalization training • 5 out of 17 miner groups involving women miners at least 40% of total cooperative member • Involving women miners in raising awareness activities on mercury impacts • Dissemination on gender specific result

• 4 new partnership mechanisms with funding for gender friendly and sustainable management solutions of chemicals and waste established at national and/or subnational level.
• 150,580 direct project beneficiaries (60,232 female and 90,348 male) for which the risk of mercury exposure has been reduced.
• Capacity of 18 government entities increased to improve their capacity to assess, plan, and implement sustainable and mercury-free interventions in the ASGM sector • 12 policies, regulations and standards revised and/or developed to improve the enabling environment for ASGM and mercury phase-out in the ASGM sector. • 3 new/improved financial products/mechanisms (including women friendly financial products) established for the ASGM sector • US$ 46 million (Total amount of funding) available to the ASGM sector through existing/new financial mechanisms. • 8 miner groups (of which 20% of the miners are women) are trained in developing a loan/investment application (incl. undertaking technical and financial feasibility studies). • 10 loan applications developed (with technical support of the project). • 55% of loan applications (developed with technical support of the project) approved. • Mercury use/releases from ASGM avoided by 10 tonnes. • 300 kg of gold produced per year without mercury • At least 50 mining groups (of which 20% of the miners are women) supported in their formalization processes. • 200 kg of mercury-free gold sold to the formal market • Awareness raised of 16,000 people (6,600 female and 9,400 male) on the dangers of mercury and ways to reduce its use in ASGM. • 24 of GEF M&E requirements met and adaptive management applied in response to needs and Mid-term Evaluation (MTE) findings. • 1 GEF GOLD country project webpage maintained. • Country project participated in 1 Global ASGM Forum, 1 Annual Programme Conference, and 12 monthly programme/project calls on a yearly basis • Opportunities for communication of project activity results at a global level are identified on a quarterly basis in collaboration with the GEF GOLD global component • On a quarterly basis, information on project progress (using agreed metrics and templates provided by the GEF GOLD global component where appropriate) is submitted to the GEF GOLD global component.
